titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the David Bourdon papers, 1941-1998, in the Archives of American Art AAA.bourdavi
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Valerie Vanden Bossche
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 216495

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-07-01T11:49-0400

did.abstract: The papers of New York art critic and writer David Bourdon measure 37 linear feet and date from 1941–1998. The papers include scattered biographical materials, manuscript and published writings, extensive art and artists' research files, and printed materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: David Bourdon (1934-1998) was an art critic, editor, and author who worked primarily in New York City.

David Bourdon was born in 1934 in California but moved to New York City to attend Columbia University and continued to live there for most of his life. He wrote for numerous art publications and was known for his sharp insight and wit. From 1964 to 1966 and 1974 to 1977 he served as art critic for the Village Voice, was assistant editor of Life magazine from 1966 to 1971, associate editor of the Smithsonian Magazine from 1972 to 1974, and art critic for Vogue magazine from 1978 to 1983 when he became senior features editor. Bourdon was also a senior editor for GEO magazine in the early 1980s and New York correspondent for du magazine for about three years in the 1970s. He was a frequent contributor to Art in America, and, in the summer of 1977 produced a show-by-show review of the entire New York art season. Bourdon also served as president of the U.S. section of the International Association of Art Critics.

Bourdon was friends with many artists, including Andy Warhol, whom he met in the 1950s while Warhol was working as a commercial artist. Bourdon wrote a book on Warhol (1989) and was involved in the some of Warhol's Factory projects, including the 1963 series of Elvis Presley silk screens. Bourdon wrote about the Manhattan art world of the early 1960s and was one of the early writers on the Minimalist moement. He also wrote about the Earth Art movement in the 1960s-1970s and was friends with Robert Smithson and Michael Heizer. He wrote Designing the Earth: the Human Impulse to Shape Nature which was published in 1995. He also wrote books on Christo (1972) and Alexander Calder (1980).
David Bourdon died in 1998 at the age of 63.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The David Bourdon papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. They may be used for research, study and scholarship. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The David Bourdon papers were donated to the Archives of American Art by Les Levine, executor of the David Bourdon estate.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of New York art critic and writer David Bourdon measure 37 linear feet and date from 1941–1998. The papers include scattered biographical materials, manuscript and published writings, extensive art and artists' research files, and printed materials.

Biographical materials consist of school writings; 2 folders of correspondence, including correspondence with Ray Johnson; Bourdon's mother’s family reminiscences, and other personal scattered materials. Writings include essays, stories, articles, and manuscript material for the books Calder: Mobilist, Ringmaster, Innovator (1980) and Designing the Earth: the Human Impulse to Shape Nature (1995). The bulk of Bourdon papers consist of his compiled research files on art, artists, sculpture, architecture and design, earth art, and for his book Designing the Earth. Individual research files may include printed materials, correspondence, writings, interview transcripts, notes, photographs, and press releases. Printed material covers many of the same subjects as those found in the research files as well Bourdon’s published writings.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Additional David Bourdon papers are located at the Museum of Modern Art Archives in New York.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was re-boxed by Joy Weiner. The collection was minimally processed and a finding aid created by Valerie Vanden Bossche in 2014 with funding provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund.

The Archives of American Art has implemented minimal processing tactics when possible in order to increase information about and access to more of our collections. Minimal processing included arrangement to the series, subseries and folder levels. Generally, items within folders were simply verified with folder titles, but not arranged further. The collection was rehoused in archival containers and folders, but not all staples and clips were removed.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: David Bourdon papers, 1941-2000. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 4 series. The found order has been maintained and is assumed to be that of David Bourdon.

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Materials, 1949-1997 (0.6 linear feet; Box 1)
Series 3: Research files, 1945-1998 (25.8 linear feet; Boxes 2-28)

controlaccess.subject: Art critics -- New York (State) -- New York
Art, Modern
Authors -- New York (State) -- New York
Pop art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Scattered biographical materials include school notebooks, files on topics of interest, family events, and family history. There is one folder of miscellaneous correspondence and one folder of two items from Ray Johnson (additional Johnson correspondence can be found in Series 3, subseries 4.)

"Erasable Structures" - Visual Arts Gallery 1971 - Guest Directed by David Bourdon
Garden Committee - 315 W. 23rd Street Owner's Corp.
"I Have Seen it All" by Marilyn Bourdon nee Edith Casale

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically, except book materials which are arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writings include essays, stories, articles, and research materials and manuscript drafts of Bourdon's books Calder and Designing the Earth (early drafts are titled “Earthbound”.) There are also drafts of his “Collected Writings,” some contracts, and a file marked current projects. Some files also include correspondence, press releases, brochures, clippings, and notes. Additonal writings are found among the research files, and published versions of Bourdon's writings are filed with Printed Materials.

did.unittitle: Book - Designing the Earth - Pictures, Rejected
"Collected Writings" II - Pop Art, IV Happenings/Performance, V Abstraction, VI Figurative Art, VII Photography

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bourdon assembled extensive research/subject files on a wide variety of art topics and artists, such as American art, art prices and collecting, forgeries, photography, sculpture, Gregory Battcock, Nam June Paik, Ray Johnson, and Pop art, among many other topics. There are extensive files on Andy Warhol and earth art in support of his books. Contents of folders vary, but typically include printed materials, contract agreements, correspondence, draft writings, interview transcripts, memos to editors, newsletters, notes, photographs, and press releases.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material, then chronologically where possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed materials inlcude published books, clippings, gallery and museum literature, periodicals, three videos, and print versions of Bourdon’s writings. The most extensive coverage is of Bourdon’s published writings, and of Andy Warhol and his circle. Other subjects include animal welfare, dance, theatre, glass art (especially Dale Chihuly), modern art, and the art world. A number of materials are annotated by Bourdon, and there are also some autographs and dedications. Also included are some periodicals for which Bourdon served as an editor. Also found are scattered published books written by others about Andy Warhol, and other topics that interested Bourdon.
